thread.title: CNY Great Pumpkin Festival, Hallowrun for Hunger: 13 things to do this weekend
thread.title_full: CNY Great Pumpkin Festival, Hallowrun for Hunger: 13 things to do this weekend | syracuse.com

author: Katrina Tulloch | ktulloch@syracuse.com
title: CNY Great Pumpkin Festival, Hallowrun for Hunger: 13 things to do this weekend
text:
Blues player Devon Allman. Provided photo SYRACUSE, N.Y. -- The weather has certainly cooled down, folks, but it's not unpleasant. Go out on this first weekend of October and enjoy the pumpkin patches and apple orchards before it become too blustery. After you've gathered enough fruit to last you all fall, check out one of the many events going on in CNY.
1. Devon Allman Band
The blues-roots-playing son of Gregg Allman returns to Syracuse just months after headlining the NYS Blues Fest in Clinton Square. Proceeds from this more intimate downtown show will benefit next year's Blues Festival.
Where: Funk 'N Waffles Downtown, 313 S. Clinton St., Syracuse
When: Thursday, Oct. 1, 8 p.m.
How much: $20 in advance, $25 at the door, available via funknwaffles.com
Related: 5 more concerts to see this week
2. Rummage and Bake Sale
St. Andrew's United Methodist Church in Mottville will host its rummage and bake sale on Thursday, Oct. 1 and Friday, Oct. 2 from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Most rummage items are 25 cents. A fill-a-bag for $2 sale will be on Saturday, Oct. 3 from 9 am - noon. Handicapped accessible.
Where: St. Andrew's United Methodist Church at 4264 Jordan Rd., Mottville.
When: Thursday, Oct 1 – Saturday, Oct. 3
How much: Free to attend. Bring cash to shop.
3. Locktender's Cocktail Party and Museum Fundraiser
The Erie Canal Museum hosts its first Locktender's cocktail party and museum fundraiser with wine tastings courtesy of the Cayuga Lake Wine Trail, beer samplings courtesy of Eastwood Brewing Company, food from Karen's Catering, sweet treats from Speach Family Candy Company, a silent auction and the chance to check out a historic Syracuse landmark. All proceeds benefit the mission and programs of the museum and the only existing weighlock building in the United States.
Where: Erie Canal Museum at 318 Erie Blvd E.
When: Friday, Oct. 2 from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m.
How much: Tickets are $50 per person.
4. Skaneateles Fall Festival & Art Studio Tour
Enjoy the stunning fall scenery surrounding Skaneateles Lake and the festively decorated village. The Skaneateles Fall Fest kicks off with First Friday starting at 5 p.m. Build a scarecrow in Clift Park from 10 a.m. - 4 p.m. on Saturday (rain location: Skaneateles YMCA at 97 State St.) or enjoy horse and wagon rides on Saturday & Sunday from noon to 4 p.m. departing from the Sherwood Inn.
Where: Downtown Skaneateles at Genesee, Jordan and Fennell streets.
When: Friday, Oct. 2 – Sunday, Oct. 4 until 5 p.m. each day.
How much: Free and open to the public.
5. Little Black Dress Event
Pull out your favorite little black dress and head to SKY Armory to support women entrepreneurs and the WISE Women's Business Center. The evening will feature a strolling fashion show with LBDs provided by Showoffs, Neenee's, and Cocli Collection. Enjoy cocktails, wines made by female winemakers, hors d'oeuvres, small plates and desserts prepared by the talented SKY Armory culinary team, live music, dancing and entertainment.
Where: SKY Armory at 351 S. Clinton St., Syracuse.
When: Friday, Oct. 2 from 6 to 10 p.m.
How much: Tickets are $65 per person.
6. Kaleidoscope Dance Theatre celebrates 25 years
Kaleidoscope Dance Theatre, a professional dance company, is based in NYC and Auburn. It is the oldest African-American-run arts organization in Auburn and Cayuga Counties and will celebrate 25 years this season with performances, residencies and workshops. Sean McLeod, an award-winning producer and choreographer, will kick off the celebrations with a dance concert this weekend.
Where: Skaneateles High School auditorium at 49 E. Elizabeth St.
When: Friday, Oct. 2 and Saturday, Oct. 3 at 7 p.m.
How much: Tickets cost $22 general admission, $18 for students and seniors and $13 for student rush.
Ephraim LaGrow, 1, of Chittenango plays peek-a-boo while pumpkin picking at Critz Farms in Cazenovia, N.Y., Saturday Sept. 26, 2015. Scott Schild | sschild@syracuse.com 7. Critz Farms Fall Harvest Celebration
The Rosamond Gifford Zoo and Friends of the Zoo teamed up with Cazenovia's Critz Farms this fall for the farm's annual Fall Harvest Celebration , which continues until Oct. 25. The theme for the corn maze this year is the "Giant Zoo-Tastic Octopus's Garden." Critz Farms designed the maze in honor of the zoo's giant Pacific octopus exhibit. The maze design includes an octopus, seahorse, fish, anemones and the letters "RG ZOO." The Fall Harvest Celebration also includes apple and pumpkin picking, wagon rides, live music, cider-making demonstrations, an animal area, a cow train and a tasting room.
Where: Critz Farms at 3232 Rippleton Rd. (Route 13) in Cazenovia.
When: Weekly through Oct. 25. Hours Monday through Friday are 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. On Saturday and Sunday, hours are 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.
How much: Admission is $7.50 per person on weekend days, with a $30 per car maximum (No family riding together in one car pays more than $30). Kids younger than 2 are free, and seniors are $5.
8. National Women's Hall of Fame: 2015 Induction
The National Women's Hall of Fame in Seneca Falls will induct a few great women on Oct. 3, including Tenley Albright, the first American woman to win a world figure skating championship and the first woman to serve as an officer in the U.S. Olympic Committee and Eleanor Smeal, Founder of the Feminist Majority, Feminist of the Year Awards, among several others. The induction starts with a luncheon, followed by the induction ceremony and a gala reception.
Where and when: Saturday, Oct. 3. The noon luncheon and the induction ceremony take place at the New York Chiropractic College gym at 2360 New York 89, Seneca Falls. The gala reception at 7 p.m. takes place at the Gould Hotel at 108 Fall St.
How much: Admission starts $35 at womenofthehall.org .
Beer fans can attend the Ballpark Brewfest Oct. 3 at NBT Bank Stadium in Syracuse. Gary Walts | gwalts@syracuse.com 9. Ballpark Brewfest
At the Ballpark Brewfest , NBT Stadium will host more than 40 breweries from across the nation as well as many from Central New York. In addition to over 80+ craft beers, there will be wine tastings as well. Find more information on ballparkbrewfestcny.com . Concession stands will be open and 4 oz. sampling glasses will be provided.
Where: NBT Stadium at 1 Tex Simone Dr.
When: Saturday, Oct. 3 from 1 to 4 p.m.
How much: Tickets are $35 before Oct. 3 or $45 on the day of the event. Parking is free. Admission is free for designated drivers.
10. CNY Great Pumpkin Festival
The Central New York Great Pumpkin Festival is one of four giant pumpkin festivals in New York State, drawing thousands of people each year. This year, the festival takes place in Oswego's Washington Park. The annual festival features kids' activities, amusement rides, vendors, crafters, fresh produce, food for purchase, pony rides and the popular pumpkin toss, with pumpkins of varying weights for varying ages. There will also be a scarecrow-making contest and best-tasting pie contest at the Great Pumpkin weigh-in.
Where: Washington Park, Oswego.
When: Sat., Oct. 3 from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. and Sun., Oct. 4 from 11 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. The giant pumpkins will be on display on Saturday, Oct. 3 only.
How much: Free and open to the public. Street parking is also free. Bring a wallet if you plan on buying, souvenirs, food or ride tickets.
11. MMA Classic Expo
MMA Classic Fan Expo will bring fighters Dan Severn, Efrain Escudero, Felice Herrig, Carla Esparza, Matt Hamill, Frank Trigg, Joe Riggs, Lauren Murphy, Ashlee Evans-Smith, Butterbean, Mark Coleman, Art Jimmerson, Stipe Miocic, Brian Ebersole, Randa Markos and Gary Goodridge to Syracuse.
Where: Center of Progress at the NYS Fairgrounds 581 State Fair Blvd.
When: Saturday, Oct. 3 and Sunday, Oct. 4
How much: General admission starts at $15. Buy tickets at Eventbrite .
12. Baltimore Woods Homegrown Community Brunch
On Sunday, Oct. 4, Baltimore Woods Nature Center will host its first Homegrown Community Brunch to celebrate the arrival of fall and the bounty of locally produced foods. Breakfast includes French-style waffles, frittatas, pancakes, sausage, crisp fall apples, hot coffee, cider and milk. After the breakfast, guests are invited to take a walk along the nature trails and enjoy the fall scenery. (The trails are open every day from dawn to dusk with no admission fee and parking is free.)
Where: Baltimore Woods Nature Center at 4007 Bishop Hill Rd., Marcellus
When: Sunday, Oct. 4 from 8 a.m. to noon.
How much: Tickets to the Homegrown Community Brunch are $9 for adults, $6 for children ages 5-12. Kids ages 4 and younger are free and can be purchased in advance online at baltimorewoods.org . A limited number of tickets will be sold at the door. Proceeds from the brunch will support Baltimore Woods and its nature education programs.
Hallowrun for Hunger 5K at Oneida Shores Park in Brewerton Sunday, October 5, 2014. The event, benefitting the Food Bank of CNY and hosted by Cicero-North Syracuse student athletes, feature "zombies" who spook runners on the course. Michelle Gabel | mgabel@syracuse.com 13. Hallowrun for Hunger
Each Hallowrun for Hunger runner supplies 87 meals in Central New York. This fun zombie chase is organized by Cicero-North Syracuse High School student athletes to support the Food Bank of CNY.
Where: Aspen Shelter of Oneida Shores Park at 9400 Bartell Rd., Brewerton.
When: Sunday, Oct. 4. The 5K takes place at 11 a.m. and free kids' run takes place at 10 a.m.
How much: Registration is $25 at hallowrun.com, and goes directly to the Food Bank of CNY. Registrants receive a student-designed T-shirt.
Katrina Tulloch writes features and entertainment stories for Syracuse.com and The Post-Standard. Contact her: Email | Twitter | Google+
